attractions.Title: Igreja Nossa Senhora da Candelária
attractions.description: L’une des églises les plus luxueuses de Rio, qui date de 1775 mais a été achevée bien plus tard ; les éléments baroques et Renaissance de l’intérieur couvert de marbre polychrome

attractions.Title: Jardim Botânico
attractions.description: Parc de 140 ha où poussent plus de 8 000 espèces d’arbres et de plantes tropicales ; l’allée bordée de palmiers impériaux de 30 m de haut, superbes orchidées ; parc en fleurs entre septembre et décembre

attractions.Title: Lapa
attractions.description: Vieux quartier de ruelles pavées et de petits escaliers, encadrés de vieilles baraques patinées par les ans ; l’un des quartiers les plus authentiques de Rio, important lieu de la vie nocturne

attractions.Title: Monastère de Saint-Benoît (Mosteiro de São Bento)
attractions.description: Couvent fondé en 1641 par les moines bénédictins, qui abrite l’une des plus belles églises de Rio ; la simplicité de la façade, l’exubérance et la richesse des boiseries intérieures, la remarquable nef tout en rouge et or

attractions.Title: Pain de Sucre (Pão de Açúcar)
attractions.description: L’une des visites incontournables, à faire tôt le matin ou 1h avant le coucher du soleil ; accès par deux téléphériques successifs ; vue grandiose, très différente de celle dont on jouit depuis le Corcovado

attractions.Title: Parc national de Tijuca
attractions.description: Parc à la végétation luxuriante, situé sur les hauteurs de Rio ; la forêt de Tijuca, considérée comme la plus grande forêt urbaine du monde

attractions.Title: Plage d'Ipanema
attractions.description: La plage la plus snob et la plus propre de Rio, avec son beau sable blond ; Cariocas les plus branchés, forcenés du foot-volley gays

attractions.Title: Santa Teresa
attractions.description: Quartier bohème dans les hauteurs de Rio ; ses hôtels particuliers et maisons coloniales bordant des rues sinueuses ; le Museu da Chácara do Céu et ses tableaux de grands peintres brésiliens

attractions.Title: Christ rédempteur du Corcovado
attractions.description: Grande statue du Christ qui domine Rio du haut de ses 704 m, et ouvre d’autres points de vue que le Pain de Sucre ; visite indispensable pour comprendre la topographie de Rio, et panorama inoubliable

attractions.Title: Plage de Copacabana
attractions.description: Mythique quartier balnéaire ; plage longue de près de 4,5 km ; entre habitants des classes moyennes et populaires et marchands ambulants venus des favelas, un cocktail singulier

attractions.Title: Corcovado (Hunchback Mountain) and Cristo Redentor (Christ the Redeemer)
attractions.description: So named because of its distinctive steeply hunched peak, Corcovado rises over Tijuca National Park. It is home to what is probably the most recognizable image of Rio: that of the Cristo Redentor (Christ the Redeemer) statue, which seems to dominate the skyline from every side of the city. Designed by Brazilian engineer Heitor da Silva Costa, and inaugurated in 1931, the iconic open-armed statue stands on top of the 710m (2,330 ft) mountain and is itself 30m (99 ft) tall. The site is best visited via the historic cog railway, which takes 20 minutes to wind up through the forest to a station just below the summit. From here, 220 steep steps lead to the summit; alternatively take one of the lifts or escalators. Weather permitting (early morning mist is common); there are stunning views of the whole city and bay area below. After dark, floodlights illuminate the statue, providing a dramatic sight visible all across Rio.

attractions.Title: Pão de Açúcar (Sugarloaf Mountain)
attractions.description: This bare domed peak jutting into the bay between Botafogo and Copacabana vies with Corcovado as Rio's most iconic and familiar feature. Its name derives from the Portuguese name for a mound of sugar, as the rounded 394m (1,293 ft) granite massif was thought to resemble moulds used to set sugar cane.
attractions.Opening times: Daily 0800-2200; the cable car leaves every 30 minutes or when full with the last departure up from Praia Vermelha at 2000).

attractions.Title: Copacabana
attractions.description: Rio's most famous neighbourhood, Copacabana, is best known for its amazing beach that stretches in a wide sandy arc for 4km (2.5 miles). Carioca girls, in dental floss bikinis, bask in the scorching sun alongside young families, senior citizens and newly arrived tourists. The seafront is a hive of activity from dawn until dusk. Early morning joggers and power walkers pound the wavy, black and white mosaic path that fringes the beach, cyclists whizz by in the cycle lane, and the beach football pitches and volleyball courts are in constant use. As on most of Rio's beaches, strong currents make swimming hazardous, although vigilant lifeguards keep a careful watch from the numberedpostos(lookout stations).
attractions.Opening times: This super-cool neighbourhood offers an enticing blend of beach life, trendy bars and chic boutiques. The area became famous in the mid 1960s with the worldwide smash hit, 'The Girl from Ipanema'. The bar where the songwriters sat to "watch the girl passing by", now known as Garota de Ipanema, is a firm favourite among tourists.
attractions.Admission Fees: This super-cool neighbourhood offers an enticing blend of beach life, trendy bars and chic boutiques. The area became famous in the mid 1960s with the worldwide smash hit, 'The Girl from Ipanema'. The bar where the songwriters sat to "watch the girl passing by", now known as Garota de Ipanema, is a firm favourite among tourists.

attractions.Title: Ipanema
attractions.description: This super-cool neighbourhood offers an enticing blend of beach life, trendy bars and chic boutiques. The area became famous in the mid 1960s with the worldwide smash hit, 'The Girl from Ipanema'. The bar where the songwriters sat to "watch the girl passing by", now known as Garota de Ipanema, is a firm favourite among tourists.
attractions.Opening times: The epicentre of Brazilian futebol, the Estádio Maracanã is also a sporting shrine for football fans from around the world. The world's biggest stadium was originally capable of holding around 200,000 people when it was built to host the 1950 World Cup Final. Even since converting to all-seated terracing in 1999, it still has capacity for 100,000 spectators. As well as football matches, live concerts have also been held at the Maracanã. Over the years many mega stars have performed here including Frank Sinatra, Paul McCartney, the Rolling Stones and Madonna. The stadium went through an extensive programme of refurbishment in preparation for the 2014 FIFA World Cup finals and again before the 2016 Olympic Games.
attractions.Admission Fees: The epicentre of Brazilian futebol, the Estádio Maracanã is also a sporting shrine for football fans from around the world. The world's biggest stadium was originally capable of holding around 200,000 people when it was built to host the 1950 World Cup Final. Even since converting to all-seated terracing in 1999, it still has capacity for 100,000 spectators. As well as football matches, live concerts have also been held at the Maracanã. Over the years many mega stars have performed here including Frank Sinatra, Paul McCartney, the Rolling Stones and Madonna. The stadium went through an extensive programme of refurbishment in preparation for the 2014 FIFA World Cup finals and again before the 2016 Olympic Games.

attractions.Title: Estádio Maracanã (Maracanã Stadium)
attractions.description: The epicentre of Brazilian futebol, the Estádio Maracanã is also a sporting shrine for football fans from around the world. The world's biggest stadium was originally capable of holding around 200,000 people when it was built to host the 1950 World Cup Final. Even since converting to all-seated terracing in 1999, it still has capacity for 100,000 spectators. As well as football matches, live concerts have also been held at the Maracanã. Over the years many mega stars have performed here including Frank Sinatra, Paul McCartney, the Rolling Stones and Madonna. The stadium went through an extensive programme of refurbishment in preparation for the 2014 FIFA World Cup finals and again before the 2016 Olympic Games.

attractions.Title: Jardim Botânico (Botanic Gardens)
attractions.description: Rio's magnificent and historic gardens contain more than 8,000 native and imported species of flora, plus many free roaming animals, including monkeys, birds and butterflies. Considered one of the most important collections of tropical plants in the world, the Botanic Gardens were founded in 1808 by Dom João, the Prince Regent and subsequent Brazilian emperor. Its star attraction is the Aleia Barbosa Rodrigues – a pathway lined by towering Imperial Palms, all of which come from the original "Palma Mater" planted in 1842. Other highlights include a pond of giant Vitoria Regis waterlilies, as well as thousands of orchids, bromeliads, insectivorous plants and a sensory garden created with wheelchair users in mind. There are also several plant houses as well as the Museum of the Environment and a play area for families. It is best to visit in the morning when birds and other animals are most active.

attractions.Title: Centro (Centre)
attractions.description: Rio's historic downtown district provides a worthwhile break from beach life. Its museums and galleries are housed in imposing colonial building and it boasts lively back street cafes, bars and dancehalls.
attractions.Opening times: One of the last remnants of Atlantic Rainforest, Tijuca National Park is the world's largest urban forest and Brazil's only inner city national park, giving Rio residents and visitors a huge natural wonderland on its doorstep. The park embraces the city, its dense vegetation tumbling down steep mountainsides from Corcovado west to Barra de Tijuca. Much of the forest was cleared for coffee plantations in the 19th century but a reforestation project successfully restored it, bringing back many rare animals and plants to their original habitat.
attractions.Admission Fees: One of the last remnants of Atlantic Rainforest, Tijuca National Park is the world's largest urban forest and Brazil's only inner city national park, giving Rio residents and visitors a huge natural wonderland on its doorstep. The park embraces the city, its dense vegetation tumbling down steep mountainsides from Corcovado west to Barra de Tijuca. Much of the forest was cleared for coffee plantations in the 19th century but a reforestation project successfully restored it, bringing back many rare animals and plants to their original habitat.

attractions.Title: Parque Nacional da Tijuca (Tijuca National Park)
attractions.description: One of the last remnants of Atlantic Rainforest, Tijuca National Park is the world's largest urban forest and Brazil's only inner city national park, giving Rio residents and visitors a huge natural wonderland on its doorstep. The park embraces the city, its dense vegetation tumbling down steep mountainsides from Corcovado west to Barra de Tijuca. Much of the forest was cleared for coffee plantations in the 19th century but a reforestation project successfully restored it, bringing back many rare animals and plants to their original habitat.

attractions.Title: Museu de Arte Contemporanea (Modern Art Museum)
attractions.description: Oscar Niemeyer's dazzling white design appears to hover over the water's edge, a short hop across the bay in Niterói. The flying saucer-like building is still as futuristic as when it was completed in 1996. The gallery is suspended over a pond by a single pillar, while visitors enter via a sweeping curved ramp. The overall effect is light, airy, and breathtaking; the art on show inside isn't bad either. MAC's permanent collection comprises some 1,200 paintings and sculptures by major Brazilian artists and other Latin American creatives. The huge wraparound windows will distract even the most avid art lover as they afford stunning views over the water of Sugarloaf and Rio's mountainous skyline. The best way to visit the museum is via ferry from downtown Praca XV to Charitas port, which was also designed by Niemeyer.

attractions.Title: Rock climbing and abseiling on Sugarloaf Mountain
Helicopter flights over Rio de Janeiro
Samba & Rioâs African Heritage at Valongo Wharf
Igreja São Francisco da Penitência & Convento de Santo Antônio
Igreja de Nossa Senhora de Candelária
Igreja de Nossa Senhora do Rosário e São Benedito
Instituto de Pesquisa e Memória Presto Novos
Igreja de Nossa Senhora do Carmo da Antiga Sé

michelin.name: Corrientes 348 - Marina da Glória
michelin.address: Avenida Infante Dom Henrique, Rio de Janeiro, 20021-140, Brésil
michelin.description: The name of this restaurant is a reference to the famous Argentinian tango “A Media Luz”, while the number 348 corresponds to the number of the street where the first of the brand’s ventures opened in Greater São Paulo. It overlooks the Marina da Glória, hence the spectacular views from tables on the terrace, and features several spacious dining rooms and an extensive glass-fronted wine cellar. The culinary focus is of course on Argentina and choice cuts of meats cooked on the grill, including specialities such as ribeye, centre cut ribeye, filet mignon with garlic, chorizo sausage and top sirloin, all accompanied by sides designed for sharing. To finish, the “dulce de leche” pancake served with sorbet is an authentic Argentinian dessert that is truly irresistible.

michelin.name: Mäska
michelin.address: Rua Joana Angélica, 159, Rio de Janeiro, 22420-030, Brésil
michelin.description: It's worth braving the frenetic traffic along Ipanema’s narrow streets to eat at this modern but relaxed restaurant with a contemporary bistro feel and a kitchen that opens on to the dining room in which you can savour chef Danilo Parah’s “innovative and emotional” cuisine. Here, the chef showcases Asian ingredients in contemporary dishes that are generous, colourful and pleasing on the palate. The impressively varied menu is complemented by dishes inspired by ingredients available in the market, such as the highly popular spaghetti with beurre blanc and braised prawns. The dining experience and atmosphere are enhanced by Mäska’s array of refreshing cocktails.

michelin.name: Tiara
michelin.address: Rua Ataulfo De Paiva, 270 loja 111, Rio de Janeiro, 22440-900, Brésil
michelin.description: The name Tiara refers to the district (Itacoatiara) in which chef Rafa Gomes was born. Nowadays, he owns two restaurants called Itacoa and, to complete the full name, Tiara. This famous chef is known for his appearance on reality cooking shows and his impressive career thus far, including stints in leading restaurants in New York. Housed in the Rio Design Leblon complex, the restaurant boasts an elegant backdrop of soothing tones for innovative cuisine that relies on modern techniques and the use of seasonal ingredients where possible. Here, the chef elevates duck meat (a key ingredient in his story) to another level. An example of this is the aged duck lacquered with honey and spices served with pumpkin, miso and a “gastrique” sauce – a quite surreal combination!

michelin.name: Miam Miam
michelin.address: Rua General Góis Monteiro 34, Rio de Janeiro, 22290-080, Brésil
michelin.description: A restaurant that opened in Botafogo in 2005 and occupies an old property that belonged to chef Roberta Ciasca's grandmother. After graduating in France, the chef opened this restaurant that encapsulates her origins thanks to the retro furniture, cheerful and colourful decor, exposed brick walls and vintage wooden floors. The menu, which follows the concept of “comfort food”, concentrates on traditional Brazilian recipes which are always meticulously presented and based around the latest techniques, and is divided between Miam Miam’s classic (and most popular) dishes and seasonal options (which change constantly), a tasting menu, plus a midweek “executive” menu. We can particularly recommend the curried chicken and shrimp croquettes, both of which are perfect.

michelin.name: Lilia
michelin.address: Rua do Senado 45, Rio de Janeiro, 20231-005, Brésil
michelin.description: This unique restaurant, with an unremarkable façade that could easily pass unnoticed among the historic colonial-style houses in the Lapa district, is located just a few metres from the conical São Sebastião cathedral. As you walk up a long, narrow staircase, you come to this two-storey restaurant featuring brick walls and corrugated iron panelling which endow it with a spacious, uncluttered and industrial feel. Here, chef Rafael Scatolin heads up a kitchen characterised by its creativity, where the cuisine is updated daily in line with the availability of ingredients. A three-course set menu is available at lunchtime, while at dinner you can choose between options on the à la carte or an eleven-course tasting menu. And make sure you save space for the Chocolate ganache, cupuaçu caramel and cocoa crunch, which it is an absolute must!

michelin.name: Mesa do Lado
michelin.address: Rua Conde Bernadotte 26, Rio de Janeiro, 22430-200, Brésil
michelin.description: A recent innovation from the Troisgros Group and one with a completely different concept that ensures a unique dining experience. Here, inside the renowned Chez Claude restaurant in Leblon, chef Claude Troisgros offers a sensory gastronomic experience that aims to awaken all five senses. The small dining room, with seating for just 12 guests per sitting, provides the setting for a tasting menu that evolves in line with lighting effects and the projection of images that varies according to the background music. The contemporary cuisine has a strong French influence and somewhat nostalgic feel thanks to family recipes handed down through the generations. Timings are strict here so you’ll need to arrive and depart at your appointed times!

michelin.name: L'Etoile
michelin.address: Avenida Niemeyer 121, Rio de Janeiro, 22450-220, Brésil
michelin.description: L'Etoile is the perfect option if you’re planning a romantic dinner with breathtaking views. Located on the 26th floor of the imposing Sheraton Grand Rio Hotel & Resort on Leblon Beach, the restaurant boasts a sophisticated and romantic atmosphere and a menu that bears the signature of renowned chef Jean-Paul Bondoux, who reinterprets classic French techniques and combines these with Brazilian ingredients. The kitchen is under the daily charge of chef Juan Garcia Molina, who brings his own personality touch to dishes, which are available on an à la carte and a seven-course tasting menu. The creative desserts are the domain of pastry chef Mariana Ribeirinha, who conjures up delicate dishes with sublime flavours!

michelin.name: Oro
michelin.address: Avenida General San Martin 889, Rio de Janeiro, 22441-015, Brésil
michelin.description: One of those restaurants that every food-lover should get to know! The rapport formed between chef Felipe Bronze and sommelier Cecilia Aldaz works wonderfully well, with large doses of friendliness, in this charming and elegant restaurant one block from Leblon beach, where the cuisine is a fusion of Brazilian roots and cutting-edge technique. This is reflected in the Afetividade and Criatividade menus (with two and four main courses, respectively) which pay homage to the different regions of Brazil. The kitchen is situated upstairs, hence the almost constant and careful movement of trays up and down the stairs. What impressed us first and foremost was the creativity of the starters, including the superb oysters with jabuticaba, and the selection of appetisers to eat with your hands, some of which are crunchy, some Brazilian, and others inspired by Japanese cuisine.

michelin.name: Térèze
michelin.address: Rua Felicio dos Santos 15, Rio de Janeiro, 20241-260, Brésil
michelin.description: Térèze is the perfect choice if you’re on the lookout for a quiet setting for a romantic supper. It is part of the Santa Teresa Mgalley hotel, a delightful historic property built in 1850 with a sophisticated atmosphere and breathtaking views. The menu is based around a contemporary theme that uses seasonal ingredients, plus a mix of Brazilian and international recipes. Chefs Jérôme Dardillac and Luanna Malheiros conjure up surprising combinations such as the perfectly grilled octopus with a chickpea purée, ratatouille and a delicious rougail sauce. After lunch or dinner, why not prolong the enjoyment with a drink in the delightful surroundings of the charming bar?

michelin.name: Mr. Lam
michelin.address: Rua Maria Angélica 21, Rio de Janeiro, 22470-201, Brésil
michelin.description: Mr. Lam gained renowned for his culinary prowess in restaurants in New York and London, however he has run this modern, sophisticated eatery on the edge of the Rodrigo de Freitas lagoon for almost two decades. In contrast with other gastronomic restaurants these days, the majority of dishes on the menu have been mainstays since it first opened, in so doing keeping with the tradition of offering the best Chinese cuisine. Featuring a hint of cutting-edge innovation as well as a focus on top-quality ingredients, the menu boasts memorable dishes such as the lightly battered and crispy Senhor Batista prawns, with a delicious sweet and sour sauce. The restaurant is laid out on three floors, with an attractive dining room and welcoming bar on the top floor that includes picture windows and a glass roof that provide lots of natural light and stunning views.

michelin.name: Sud, O Pássaro Verde
michelin.address: Rua Visconde de Carandaí 35, Rio de Janeiro, 22460-020, Brésil
michelin.description: Walking into this restaurant is like entering the home of a friend, as you’ll need to knock on the door or announce your presence in order to be let in. Occupying a house in the quiet Jardim Botânico district, this is the domain of chef Roberta Sudbrack who describes it as a space in which to “tell and eat stories”. Inside, the decor is modest yet welcoming, with an impressive wood-fired oven next to the main dining room, plus a charming open kitchen, from which comforting home-style dishes emerge prepared with ingredients from small-scale local producers. As a result, the menu changes daily in line with market availability and freshness. However, one mainstay that is always on the menu is the superbly textured and irresistibly flavoured chocolate cake (“bolo de chocolate molhadinho”).

michelin.name: Giuseppe Grill Leblon
michelin.address: Avenida Bartolomeu Mitre 370, Rio de Janeiro, 22431-001, Brésil
michelin.description: As the name clearly states, all the dishes (fish and meat) at this restaurant are cooked on the charcoal grill. The menu here includes dry-aged meat options (T-bone, prime rib, bone-in tenderloin etc). Other standout dishes include the Maminha (sirloin trip-tip), the Picanha supra sumo (supra sumo rump cap), the brand’s registered trademark, as well as the slow-cooked Uruguayan lamb shoulder served with its own jus. A number of fish and seafood options are also on display, which vary according to availability on the day. The decor here features exposed stone walls, wooden chairs and leather sofas, all of which combine to add a rustic-elegant touch. Not forgetting the extensive wine cellar in the basement, featuring over 400 labels from different countries.

michelin.name: Território Aprazível
michelin.address: Rua Aprazível 62, Rio de Janeiro, 20241-270, Brésil
michelin.description: Aprazível is a must for those who love delicious food inspired by nature. This family-run restaurant, located inside an exuberant tropical garden and furnished in rustic style, boasts a superb view of the city. Here, chef Ana Castilho conjures up typical Brazilian dishes teeming with flavour and created using organic and biodynamic ingredients, yet without neglecting either elegance or delicacy. One of her signature dishes is the free-range “galinhada caipira”, served with a delicious free-range chicken-flavoured rice, plantains, sausage from Minas Gerais, braised cabbage, and a tasty pepper jelly and beans. Enjoy Aprazível’s pleasant atmosphere and charming setting in the company of a relaxing drink!

michelin.name: Aconchego Carioca
michelin.address: Rua Barão de Iguatemi 245, Rio de Janeiro, 20270-060, Brésil
michelin.description: A whole host of traditional dishes such as the rice-based “arroz de rabada”, “baião de dois” (black-eyed peas with rice) and the unmissable Bolinho de feijoada (fried feijoada dumplings) are just some of the dishes served in this restaurant, which has become a popular culinary focal point in the northern part of Rio de Janeiro. Here, well-known chef Kátia Barbosa creates cooking with a focus on typical Brazilian dishes with influences from the north-east of the country, all of which are prepared with meticulous detail and lots of flavour. In this completely relaxed and informal setting, decorated with hammocks hanging from the ceilings, the pleasant garden and friendly staff make you feel very much at home. Make sure you also try the innovative and amazing cocktails!

michelin.name: Chez Claude
michelin.address: Rua Conde de Bernadotte 26, Rio de Janeiro, 22430-200, Brésil
michelin.description: Run by the famous French chef Claude Troisgros, this dining space has plenty of detail to pique your interest. Firstly, the completely open kitchen in the centre of the room, enabling diners to watch dishes being prepared at close quarters, which are based around French cuisine with the addition of some Brazilian elements. And secondly, the fact that food is served in bowls for sharing, to add to the sense of home-style cooking. The staff here recommend four dishes for two people including delicacies such as the fillet steak au poivre with a sauce that will make your mouth water, accompanied by cassava puff pastry and broccoli with Grana Padano cheese. To finish your meal, don’t miss the impressively textured melted chocolate Carola cake.

michelin.name: Artigiano
michelin.address: Avenida Epitácio Pessoa 204, Rio de Janeiro, 22471-002, Brésil
michelin.description: This restaurant is a classic address in the city, offering an authentic dining experience courtesy of Emilia-Romagna, one of Northen Italy’s most iconic food regions. As its name suggests, everything is home-made in artisanal style: pastas, pizzas, sauces, breads and desserts are all made daily and cooked or finished to order. We particularly recommend the zucchini flowers stuffed with mozzarella and anchovies and served with a delicious tartare sauce. Another dish that you won’t want to miss is the garganello with lamb ragù, one of Northern Italy’s most characteristic pastas, served with a surprising yet delicious sauce.

michelin.name: Rudä
michelin.address: Rua Garcia D'Ávila, 118, Rio de Janeiro, 22421-010, Brésil
michelin.description: One of the most talked about restaurants in Ipanema. Here, chef Danilo Parah champions what he calls “emotional and creative cuisine” in a contemporary bistro-style setting featuring different ambiences and a private room on the first floor. Brazilian cuisine is very much to the fore and is showcased on a varied à la carte (plus an ”executive” menu) with a focus on local ingredients and in colourful, generous and highly flavourful dishes with little fear when it comes to combining lots of ingredients. It’s hard to forget the octopus with jambu fruit (a dish with a profusion of colours and textures that includes pasta cooked in a moqueca sauce) or the delicious cheesecake that takes on its own personality! The hospitality is on a par with the food here!

michelin.name: Nosso
michelin.address: Rua Maria Quitéria 91, Rio de Janeiro, 22410-040, Brésil
michelin.description: An exclusive restaurant with three completely different floors: on the first, a bar; on the second, a dining space with an intimate ambience for a pleasant supper; and on the third, an outdoor terrace. Here, the relaxed cuisine, which is described by chef Bruno Katz as “contemporary”, features dishes that combine different food cultures from around the world in a creative and harmonious way. One example is the glazed octopus served with fried rice, kewpie mayonnaise, moyashi and nira, which is simply divine and cooked to perfection. Bartender Daniel Estevan elevates his concoctions to another level, combining classic drinks with his experience of the Amazon to create cocktails such as the surprising Tacacá Sour, with its mix of jambu, tucupi, cupuaçu and lemon. An extraordinary experience!

michelin.name: Clan BBQ
michelin.address: Rua Dias Ferreira, 233 Loja B, Rio de Janeiro, 22431 050, Brésil
michelin.description: To the backdrop of a neon sign “Não apague o meu fogo” (“Don’t put out my fire”) clearly visible above the door, chefs Pepo Figueiredo and Newton Rique showcase cuisine in which fire plays a key role here, enabling them to prepare fresh ingredients imbued with a special flavour. In this industrial-style ambience with a predominance of raw concrete, a sturdy tree takes centre stage in the middle of the dining room. There’s also the option of sitting at the counter by the grill to watch dishes and cocktails being prepared at close quarters. The menu is of course heavily focused on barbecued meats, although you’ll also find other options such as vegetables, fish and burgers. Dishes you won’t want to miss include the creamy oxtail croquettes and cubes of smoked tongue with aioli. The succulent French rack of lamb, served with chimichurri, is cooked to perfection.

michelin.name: Henriqueta
michelin.address: Rua Aristides Espínola, Rio de Janeiro, 22440-050, Brésil
michelin.description: This “tasca” style restaurant in the southern part of Rio de Janeiro showcases the best of Portuguese cuisine in a bright environment with a glass façade, open kitchen and Portuguese ceramic decoration. The cuisine on offer dispenses with unnecessary frills, focusing on the quality of the ingredients and dishes designed for sharing, among which the “biff-anas açorianas”, a crispy bread sandwich filled with pork escalope marinated in wine and garlic, stands out. As a main course, we recommend the tender octopus “a lagareiro” roasted in oil, served with onion confit and mashed potatoes, followed by the “toucinho do céu” made with egg yolks, almonds and cinnamon, an authentic Portuguese dish if ever there was one!

michelin.name: Corrientes 348 - Marina da Glória
michelin.address: Avenida Infante Dom Henrique, Rio de Janeiro, 20021-140, Brésil
michelin.description: The name of this restaurant is a reference to the famous Argentinian tango “A Media Luz”, while the number 348 corresponds to the number of the street where the first of the brand’s ventures opened in Greater São Paulo. It overlooks the Marina da Glória, hence the spectacular views from tables on the terrace, and features several spacious dining rooms and an extensive glass-fronted wine cellar. The culinary focus is of course on Argentina and choice cuts of meats cooked on the grill, including specialities such as ribeye, centre cut ribeye, filet mignon with garlic, chorizo sausage and top sirloin, all accompanied by sides designed for sharing. To finish, the “dulce de leche” pancake served with sorbet is an authentic Argentinian dessert that is truly irresistible.

michelin.name: Mäska
michelin.address: Rua Joana Angélica, 159, Rio de Janeiro, 22420-030, Brésil
michelin.description: It's worth braving the frenetic traffic along Ipanema’s narrow streets to eat at this modern but relaxed restaurant with a contemporary bistro feel and a kitchen that opens on to the dining room in which you can savour chef Danilo Parah’s “innovative and emotional” cuisine. Here, the chef showcases Asian ingredients in contemporary dishes that are generous, colourful and pleasing on the palate. The impressively varied menu is complemented by dishes inspired by ingredients available in the market, such as the highly popular spaghetti with beurre blanc and braised prawns. The dining experience and atmosphere are enhanced by Mäska’s array of refreshing cocktails.

michelin.name: Tiara
michelin.address: Rua Ataulfo De Paiva, 270 loja 111, Rio de Janeiro, 22440-900, Brésil
michelin.description: The name Tiara refers to the district (Itacoatiara) in which chef Rafa Gomes was born. Nowadays, he owns two restaurants called Itacoa and, to complete the full name, Tiara. This famous chef is known for his appearance on reality cooking shows and his impressive career thus far, including stints in leading restaurants in New York. Housed in the Rio Design Leblon complex, the restaurant boasts an elegant backdrop of soothing tones for innovative cuisine that relies on modern techniques and the use of seasonal ingredients where possible. Here, the chef elevates duck meat (a key ingredient in his story) to another level. An example of this is the aged duck lacquered with honey and spices served with pumpkin, miso and a “gastrique” sauce – a quite surreal combination!

michelin.name: Miam Miam
michelin.address: Rua General Góis Monteiro 34, Rio de Janeiro, 22290-080, Brésil
michelin.description: A restaurant that opened in Botafogo in 2005 and occupies an old property that belonged to chef Roberta Ciasca's grandmother. After graduating in France, the chef opened this restaurant that encapsulates her origins thanks to the retro furniture, cheerful and colourful decor, exposed brick walls and vintage wooden floors. The menu, which follows the concept of “comfort food”, concentrates on traditional Brazilian recipes which are always meticulously presented and based around the latest techniques, and is divided between Miam Miam’s classic (and most popular) dishes and seasonal options (which change constantly), a tasting menu, plus a midweek “executive” menu. We can particularly recommend the curried chicken and shrimp croquettes, both of which are perfect.

michelin.name: Lilia
michelin.address: Rua do Senado 45, Rio de Janeiro, 20231-005, Brésil
michelin.description: This unique restaurant, with an unremarkable façade that could easily pass unnoticed among the historic colonial-style houses in the Lapa district, is located just a few metres from the conical São Sebastião cathedral. As you walk up a long, narrow staircase, you come to this two-storey restaurant featuring brick walls and corrugated iron panelling which endow it with a spacious, uncluttered and industrial feel. Here, chef Rafael Scatolin heads up a kitchen characterised by its creativity, where the cuisine is updated daily in line with the availability of ingredients. A three-course set menu is available at lunchtime, while at dinner you can choose between options on the à la carte or an eleven-course tasting menu. And make sure you save space for the Chocolate ganache, cupuaçu caramel and cocoa crunch, which it is an absolute must!

michelin.name: Mesa do Lado
michelin.address: Rua Conde Bernadotte 26, Rio de Janeiro, 22430-200, Brésil
michelin.description: A recent innovation from the Troisgros Group and one with a completely different concept that ensures a unique dining experience. Here, inside the renowned Chez Claude restaurant in Leblon, chef Claude Troisgros offers a sensory gastronomic experience that aims to awaken all five senses. The small dining room, with seating for just 12 guests per sitting, provides the setting for a tasting menu that evolves in line with lighting effects and the projection of images that varies according to the background music. The contemporary cuisine has a strong French influence and somewhat nostalgic feel thanks to family recipes handed down through the generations. Timings are strict here so you’ll need to arrive and depart at your appointed times!

michelin.name: L'Etoile
michelin.address: Avenida Niemeyer 121, Rio de Janeiro, 22450-220, Brésil
michelin.description: L'Etoile is the perfect option if you’re planning a romantic dinner with breathtaking views. Located on the 26th floor of the imposing Sheraton Grand Rio Hotel & Resort on Leblon Beach, the restaurant boasts a sophisticated and romantic atmosphere and a menu that bears the signature of renowned chef Jean-Paul Bondoux, who reinterprets classic French techniques and combines these with Brazilian ingredients. The kitchen is under the daily charge of chef Juan Garcia Molina, who brings his own personality touch to dishes, which are available on an à la carte and a seven-course tasting menu. The creative desserts are the domain of pastry chef Mariana Ribeirinha, who conjures up delicate dishes with sublime flavours!

michelin.name: Oro
michelin.address: Avenida General San Martin 889, Rio de Janeiro, 22441-015, Brésil
michelin.description: One of those restaurants that every food-lover should get to know! The rapport formed between chef Felipe Bronze and sommelier Cecilia Aldaz works wonderfully well, with large doses of friendliness, in this charming and elegant restaurant one block from Leblon beach, where the cuisine is a fusion of Brazilian roots and cutting-edge technique. This is reflected in the Afetividade and Criatividade menus (with two and four main courses, respectively) which pay homage to the different regions of Brazil. The kitchen is situated upstairs, hence the almost constant and careful movement of trays up and down the stairs. What impressed us first and foremost was the creativity of the starters, including the superb oysters with jabuticaba, and the selection of appetisers to eat with your hands, some of which are crunchy, some Brazilian, and others inspired by Japanese cuisine.

michelin.name: Térèze
michelin.address: Rua Felicio dos Santos 15, Rio de Janeiro, 20241-260, Brésil
michelin.description: Térèze is the perfect choice if you’re on the lookout for a quiet setting for a romantic supper. It is part of the Santa Teresa Mgalley hotel, a delightful historic property built in 1850 with a sophisticated atmosphere and breathtaking views. The menu is based around a contemporary theme that uses seasonal ingredients, plus a mix of Brazilian and international recipes. Chefs Jérôme Dardillac and Luanna Malheiros conjure up surprising combinations such as the perfectly grilled octopus with a chickpea purée, ratatouille and a delicious rougail sauce. After lunch or dinner, why not prolong the enjoyment with a drink in the delightful surroundings of the charming bar?

michelin.name: Mr. Lam
michelin.address: Rua Maria Angélica 21, Rio de Janeiro, 22470-201, Brésil
michelin.description: Mr. Lam gained renowned for his culinary prowess in restaurants in New York and London, however he has run this modern, sophisticated eatery on the edge of the Rodrigo de Freitas lagoon for almost two decades. In contrast with other gastronomic restaurants these days, the majority of dishes on the menu have been mainstays since it first opened, in so doing keeping with the tradition of offering the best Chinese cuisine. Featuring a hint of cutting-edge innovation as well as a focus on top-quality ingredients, the menu boasts memorable dishes such as the lightly battered and crispy Senhor Batista prawns, with a delicious sweet and sour sauce. The restaurant is laid out on three floors, with an attractive dining room and welcoming bar on the top floor that includes picture windows and a glass roof that provide lots of natural light and stunning views.

michelin.name: Sud, O Pássaro Verde
michelin.address: Rua Visconde de Carandaí 35, Rio de Janeiro, 22460-020, Brésil
michelin.description: Walking into this restaurant is like entering the home of a friend, as you’ll need to knock on the door or announce your presence in order to be let in. Occupying a house in the quiet Jardim Botânico district, this is the domain of chef Roberta Sudbrack who describes it as a space in which to “tell and eat stories”. Inside, the decor is modest yet welcoming, with an impressive wood-fired oven next to the main dining room, plus a charming open kitchen, from which comforting home-style dishes emerge prepared with ingredients from small-scale local producers. As a result, the menu changes daily in line with market availability and freshness. However, one mainstay that is always on the menu is the superbly textured and irresistibly flavoured chocolate cake (“bolo de chocolate molhadinho”).

michelin.name: Giuseppe Grill Leblon
michelin.address: Avenida Bartolomeu Mitre 370, Rio de Janeiro, 22431-001, Brésil
michelin.description: As the name clearly states, all the dishes (fish and meat) at this restaurant are cooked on the charcoal grill. The menu here includes dry-aged meat options (T-bone, prime rib, bone-in tenderloin etc). Other standout dishes include the Maminha (sirloin trip-tip), the Picanha supra sumo (supra sumo rump cap), the brand’s registered trademark, as well as the slow-cooked Uruguayan lamb shoulder served with its own jus. A number of fish and seafood options are also on display, which vary according to availability on the day. The decor here features exposed stone walls, wooden chairs and leather sofas, all of which combine to add a rustic-elegant touch. Not forgetting the extensive wine cellar in the basement, featuring over 400 labels from different countries.

michelin.name: Território Aprazível
michelin.address: Rua Aprazível 62, Rio de Janeiro, 20241-270, Brésil
michelin.description: Aprazível is a must for those who love delicious food inspired by nature. This family-run restaurant, located inside an exuberant tropical garden and furnished in rustic style, boasts a superb view of the city. Here, chef Ana Castilho conjures up typical Brazilian dishes teeming with flavour and created using organic and biodynamic ingredients, yet without neglecting either elegance or delicacy. One of her signature dishes is the free-range “galinhada caipira”, served with a delicious free-range chicken-flavoured rice, plantains, sausage from Minas Gerais, braised cabbage, and a tasty pepper jelly and beans. Enjoy Aprazível’s pleasant atmosphere and charming setting in the company of a relaxing drink!

michelin.name: Aconchego Carioca
michelin.address: Rua Barão de Iguatemi 245, Rio de Janeiro, 20270-060, Brésil
michelin.description: A whole host of traditional dishes such as the rice-based “arroz de rabada”, “baião de dois” (black-eyed peas with rice) and the unmissable Bolinho de feijoada (fried feijoada dumplings) are just some of the dishes served in this restaurant, which has become a popular culinary focal point in the northern part of Rio de Janeiro. Here, well-known chef Kátia Barbosa creates cooking with a focus on typical Brazilian dishes with influences from the north-east of the country, all of which are prepared with meticulous detail and lots of flavour. In this completely relaxed and informal setting, decorated with hammocks hanging from the ceilings, the pleasant garden and friendly staff make you feel very much at home. Make sure you also try the innovative and amazing cocktails!

michelin.name: Chez Claude
michelin.address: Rua Conde de Bernadotte 26, Rio de Janeiro, 22430-200, Brésil
michelin.description: Run by the famous French chef Claude Troisgros, this dining space has plenty of detail to pique your interest. Firstly, the completely open kitchen in the centre of the room, enabling diners to watch dishes being prepared at close quarters, which are based around French cuisine with the addition of some Brazilian elements. And secondly, the fact that food is served in bowls for sharing, to add to the sense of home-style cooking. The staff here recommend four dishes for two people including delicacies such as the fillet steak au poivre with a sauce that will make your mouth water, accompanied by cassava puff pastry and broccoli with Grana Padano cheese. To finish your meal, don’t miss the impressively textured melted chocolate Carola cake.

michelin.name: Artigiano
michelin.address: Avenida Epitácio Pessoa 204, Rio de Janeiro, 22471-002, Brésil
michelin.description: This restaurant is a classic address in the city, offering an authentic dining experience courtesy of Emilia-Romagna, one of Northen Italy’s most iconic food regions. As its name suggests, everything is home-made in artisanal style: pastas, pizzas, sauces, breads and desserts are all made daily and cooked or finished to order. We particularly recommend the zucchini flowers stuffed with mozzarella and anchovies and served with a delicious tartare sauce. Another dish that you won’t want to miss is the garganello with lamb ragù, one of Northern Italy’s most characteristic pastas, served with a surprising yet delicious sauce.

michelin.name: Rudä
michelin.address: Rua Garcia D'Ávila, 118, Rio de Janeiro, 22421-010, Brésil
michelin.description: One of the most talked about restaurants in Ipanema. Here, chef Danilo Parah champions what he calls “emotional and creative cuisine” in a contemporary bistro-style setting featuring different ambiences and a private room on the first floor. Brazilian cuisine is very much to the fore and is showcased on a varied à la carte (plus an ”executive” menu) with a focus on local ingredients and in colourful, generous and highly flavourful dishes with little fear when it comes to combining lots of ingredients. It’s hard to forget the octopus with jambu fruit (a dish with a profusion of colours and textures that includes pasta cooked in a moqueca sauce) or the delicious cheesecake that takes on its own personality! The hospitality is on a par with the food here!

michelin.name: Nosso
michelin.address: Rua Maria Quitéria 91, Rio de Janeiro, 22410-040, Brésil
michelin.description: An exclusive restaurant with three completely different floors: on the first, a bar; on the second, a dining space with an intimate ambience for a pleasant supper; and on the third, an outdoor terrace. Here, the relaxed cuisine, which is described by chef Bruno Katz as “contemporary”, features dishes that combine different food cultures from around the world in a creative and harmonious way. One example is the glazed octopus served with fried rice, kewpie mayonnaise, moyashi and nira, which is simply divine and cooked to perfection. Bartender Daniel Estevan elevates his concoctions to another level, combining classic drinks with his experience of the Amazon to create cocktails such as the surprising Tacacá Sour, with its mix of jambu, tucupi, cupuaçu and lemon. An extraordinary experience!

michelin.name: Clan BBQ
michelin.address: Rua Dias Ferreira, 233 Loja B, Rio de Janeiro, 22431 050, Brésil
michelin.description: To the backdrop of a neon sign “Não apague o meu fogo” (“Don’t put out my fire”) clearly visible above the door, chefs Pepo Figueiredo and Newton Rique showcase cuisine in which fire plays a key role here, enabling them to prepare fresh ingredients imbued with a special flavour. In this industrial-style ambience with a predominance of raw concrete, a sturdy tree takes centre stage in the middle of the dining room. There’s also the option of sitting at the counter by the grill to watch dishes and cocktails being prepared at close quarters. The menu is of course heavily focused on barbecued meats, although you’ll also find other options such as vegetables, fish and burgers. Dishes you won’t want to miss include the creamy oxtail croquettes and cubes of smoked tongue with aioli. The succulent French rack of lamb, served with chimichurri, is cooked to perfection.

michelin.name: Henriqueta
michelin.address: Rua Aristides Espínola, Rio de Janeiro, 22440-050, Brésil
michelin.description: This “tasca” style restaurant in the southern part of Rio de Janeiro showcases the best of Portuguese cuisine in a bright environment with a glass façade, open kitchen and Portuguese ceramic decoration. The cuisine on offer dispenses with unnecessary frills, focusing on the quality of the ingredients and dishes designed for sharing, among which the “biff-anas açorianas”, a crispy bread sandwich filled with pork escalope marinated in wine and garlic, stands out. As a main course, we recommend the tender octopus “a lagareiro” roasted in oil, served with onion confit and mashed potatoes, followed by the “toucinho do céu” made with egg yolks, almonds and cinnamon, an authentic Portuguese dish if ever there was one!

michelin.name: Corrientes 348 - Marina da Glória
michelin.address: Avenida Infante Dom Henrique, Rio de Janeiro, 20021-140, Brésil
michelin.description: The name of this restaurant is a reference to the famous Argentinian tango “A Media Luz”, while the number 348 corresponds to the number of the street where the first of the brand’s ventures opened in Greater São Paulo. It overlooks the Marina da Glória, hence the spectacular views from tables on the terrace, and features several spacious dining rooms and an extensive glass-fronted wine cellar. The culinary focus is of course on Argentina and choice cuts of meats cooked on the grill, including specialities such as ribeye, centre cut ribeye, filet mignon with garlic, chorizo sausage and top sirloin, all accompanied by sides designed for sharing. To finish, the “dulce de leche” pancake served with sorbet is an authentic Argentinian dessert that is truly irresistible.

michelin.name: Mäska
michelin.address: Rua Joana Angélica, 159, Rio de Janeiro, 22420-030, Brésil
michelin.description: It's worth braving the frenetic traffic along Ipanema’s narrow streets to eat at this modern but relaxed restaurant with a contemporary bistro feel and a kitchen that opens on to the dining room in which you can savour chef Danilo Parah’s “innovative and emotional” cuisine. Here, the chef showcases Asian ingredients in contemporary dishes that are generous, colourful and pleasing on the palate. The impressively varied menu is complemented by dishes inspired by ingredients available in the market, such as the highly popular spaghetti with beurre blanc and braised prawns. The dining experience and atmosphere are enhanced by Mäska’s array of refreshing cocktails.

michelin.name: Tiara
michelin.address: Rua Ataulfo De Paiva, 270 loja 111, Rio de Janeiro, 22440-900, Brésil
michelin.description: The name Tiara refers to the district (Itacoatiara) in which chef Rafa Gomes was born. Nowadays, he owns two restaurants called Itacoa and, to complete the full name, Tiara. This famous chef is known for his appearance on reality cooking shows and his impressive career thus far, including stints in leading restaurants in New York. Housed in the Rio Design Leblon complex, the restaurant boasts an elegant backdrop of soothing tones for innovative cuisine that relies on modern techniques and the use of seasonal ingredients where possible. Here, the chef elevates duck meat (a key ingredient in his story) to another level. An example of this is the aged duck lacquered with honey and spices served with pumpkin, miso and a “gastrique” sauce – a quite surreal combination!

michelin.description: To the backdrop of a neon sign “Não apague o meu fogo” (“Don’t put out my fire”) clearly visible above the door, chefs Pepo Figueiredo and Newton Rique showcase cuisine in which fire plays a key role here, enabling them to prepare fresh ingredients imbued with a special flavour. In this industrial-style ambience with a predominance of raw concrete, a sturdy tree takes centre stage in the middle of the dining room. There’s also the option of sitting at the counter by the grill to watch dishes and cocktails being prepared at close quarters. The menu is of course heavily focused on barbecued meats, although you’ll also find other options such as vegetables, fish and burgers. Dishes you won’t want to miss include the creamy oxtail croquettes and cubes of smoked tongue with aioli. The succulent French rack of lamb, served with chimichurri, is cooked to perfection.

michelin.name: Henriqueta
michelin.address: Rua Aristides Espínola, Rio de Janeiro, 22440-050, Brésil
michelin.description: This “tasca” style restaurant in the southern part of Rio de Janeiro showcases the best of Portuguese cuisine in a bright environment with a glass façade, open kitchen and Portuguese ceramic decoration. The cuisine on offer dispenses with unnecessary frills, focusing on the quality of the ingredients and dishes designed for sharing, among which the “biff-anas açorianas”, a crispy bread sandwich filled with pork escalope marinated in wine and garlic, stands out. As a main course, we recommend the tender octopus “a lagareiro” roasted in oil, served with onion confit and mashed potatoes, followed by the “toucinho do céu” made with egg yolks, almonds and cinnamon, an authentic Portuguese dish if ever there was one!
